qas.question: When did tides and currents similar to our current system begin?
Why did natural sedimentation by the Rhine compensate the transgression bby the sea?

answers.text: Rates of sea-level rise had dropped

qas.question: How long has the Rhine coastline been in the same location?
Why is the current sea level rising?
How quickly is the sea level rising?
When did tides and currents reach the highest sea-level rise?
How quickly is the sea level dropping?
How long has the ongoing tectonic subsidence in the southern North Sea been happening for?
How high is the natural sedimentation by the Rhine?
How old is the North Sea?

context: Since <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0><b7_0>7500 yr<b7_0/> ago<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, a situation with tides and currents, very similar to present has existed. <a1_0><a1_2>Rates of <a1_1>sea-level rise<a1_0/> had dropped<a1_2/><a1_1/> so far, that natural sedimentation by the Rhine and coastal processes together, could compensate the transgression by the sea; in the <a2_0><a2_2>last <a2_1><b9_0>7000 years<b9_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, the coast line was roughly at the same location. In the southern North Sea, due to <a3_2>ongoing <a3_0><a3_1>tectonic subsidence<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, the sea level is still rising, at the rate of about <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b6_0><b8_0>1–3 cm (0.39–1.18 in)<b8_0/><b6_0/> per century<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> (1 metre or 39 inches in last 3000 years).
